case_vignette: A 45-year old man comes to the physician because of a painless neck lump and a 2-month history of difficulty swallowing. He has a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis and episodic hypertension. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3-cm, nontender nodule at the level of the thyroid cartilage. A photomicrograph of a section of tissue obtained by core needle biopsy of the nodule is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Endocrinology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got a lump on my neck that doesn't hurt, and I've been having trouble swallowing for the last two months.
How old are you?
I'm 45 years old.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms like weight loss, heart palpitations, or changes in your energy levels?
No, I haven't noticed those symptoms.
Is the lump on one side of your neck or in the middle?
It's in the middle of my neck.
Have you had any changes in your voice or hoarseness recently?
No, my voice has been normal, no hoarseness or changes.
Have you experienced any trouble breathing or a feeling of tightness in the throat?
No, I haven't had any trouble breathing or a feeling of tightness in my throat.
Have you or anyone in your family had thyroid problems or any other endocrine disorders?
I can't say; I don't have any information about that.
Have you noticed any enlargement in other areas of your neck or other lumps?
No, just this one lump on my neck.
Have you ever had any radiation exposure to your head or neck area?
I don't know about that.
Is the lump moving when you swallow?
I'm not sure if it moves when I swallow.
Have you had any recent infections or illnesses, like a cold or sore throat, before noticing the lump?
No, I haven't had any recent infections or illnesses.
Have you been experiencing any night sweats or unexplained fevers?
No, I haven't had night sweats or unexplained fevers.

Final Diagnosis: Given the presence of a non-painful, midline neck lump and difficulty swallowing without other systemic symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is a thyroid nodule or goiter. Further evaluation with thyroid function tests and imaging, like an ultrasound of the thyroid, is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and guide management.
